title: What is Leukemia?
description: Learn the fundamentals of leukemia and how it affects your blood and body.

questions.questionText: Leukemia is a cancer that primarily affects which part of the body?
questions.explanation: Leukemia is a cancer of blood-forming tissues, including bone marrow and the lymphatic system. It causes abnormal white blood cell production.

questions.questionText: Leukemia is contagious and can spread from person to person.
questions.explanation: Leukemia is NOT contagious. It's caused by genetic mutations in blood cells, not by any virus or bacteria that can spread.

questions.questionText: Which type of blood cell is most affected in leukemia?
questions.explanation: In leukemia, the bone marrow produces abnormal white blood cells (leukocytes) that don't function properly and crowd out healthy cells.

questions.questionText: Leukemia originates in the _____, where blood cells are made.
questions.explanation: Bone marrow is the spongy tissue inside bones where all blood cells are produced. Leukemia begins when mutations occur in this tissue.

questions.questionText: Leukemia can occur in both children and adults.
questions.explanation: Leukemia affects people of all ages. In fact, it is one of the most common cancers in children, but certain types are more prevalent in adults.

title: Types of Leukemia
description: Discover the four main types of leukemia and what makes each one unique.

questions.questionText: Which leukemia type is most common in children?
questions.explanation: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) is the most common cancer in children, though it can occur in adults too.

questions.questionText: What does 'acute' mean in the context of leukemia?
questions.explanation: 'Acute' leukemia progresses quickly and requires immediate treatment. 'Chronic' leukemia develops more slowly.

questions.questionText: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is most common in older adults.
questions.explanation: CLL predominantly affects adults over 60 and is rarely seen in children. It's one of the most common leukemias in the Western world.

questions.questionText: AML stands for:
questions.explanation: AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia) is a fast-growing cancer that starts in myeloid cells - the cells that normally develop into red blood cells, platelets, and some white blood cells.

questions.questionText: There are _____ main types of leukemia classified by speed of progression and cell type.
questions.explanation: The four main types are ALL, AML, CLL, and CML — classified as either acute or chronic, and either lymphocytic or myeloid.

title: Early Warning Signs
description: Recognize the early symptoms of leukemia that you should never ignore.

questions.questionText: Which of these is a common early sign of leukemia?
questions.explanation: Persistent fatigue is one of the most common early signs of leukemia, caused by anemia from reduced red blood cell production.

questions.questionText: Frequent infections can be a warning sign of leukemia.
questions.explanation: Abnormal white blood cells in leukemia don't fight infections properly, leading to frequent, severe, or unusual infections.

questions.questionText: Why do leukemia patients often experience unexplained bruising or bleeding?
options: Low platelet count from crowded bone marrow
questions.correctAnswer: Low platelet count from crowded bone marrow
questions.explanation: When leukemia cells crowd the bone marrow, fewer platelets are produced. Platelets are essential for blood clotting, so low counts cause easy bruising and bleeding.

questions.questionText: Swollen lymph nodes in the neck, armpits, or groin can be a sign of leukemia.
questions.explanation: Swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) occur when leukemia cells accumulate in lymph nodes. They are usually painless.

questions.questionText: If you notice several of these symptoms together, what should you do?
options: Wait to see if they go away
questions.explanation: Early detection significantly improves treatment outcomes. Never ignore a combination of these symptoms — see a doctor for proper blood tests.

title: Risk Factors
description: Understand what increases the risk of developing leukemia.

questions.questionText: Which genetic condition is associated with an increased risk of leukemia?
questions.explanation: Children with Down syndrome (trisomy 21) have a 10-20x higher risk of developing acute leukemia compared to children without the condition.

questions.questionText: Exposure to high levels of radiation increases the risk of leukemia.
questions.explanation: Radiation exposure, such as from atomic bomb survivors or previous radiation therapy, significantly increases leukemia risk, particularly AML.

questions.questionText: Which chemical exposure is linked to leukemia risk?
questions.explanation: Benzene is an industrial chemical found in cigarette smoke, gasoline, and some plastics. Long-term exposure is strongly linked to AML development.

questions.questionText: Smoking is a risk factor for leukemia.
questions.explanation: Smoking exposes the body to benzene and other carcinogens, increasing the risk of AML by approximately 40%.

questions.questionText: Having a family history of leukemia slightly increases your _____ of developing it.
questions.explanation: While most leukemia cases are not directly inherited, having a first-degree relative with certain types of leukemia does increase your personal risk.

title: Treatment Options
description: Explore the main treatments available for leukemia patients today.

questions.questionText: What is the most common first-line treatment for acute leukemia?
questions.explanation: Chemotherapy uses drugs to kill or stop the growth of cancer cells. It is the primary treatment for most leukemia types, often given in cycles.

questions.questionText: A bone marrow transplant can potentially cure some types of leukemia.
questions.explanation: Stem cell (bone marrow) transplants replace diseased bone marrow with healthy donor cells and can offer a cure for eligible patients, particularly for AML and ALL.

questions.questionText: What does targeted therapy do differently from traditional chemotherapy?
options: It targets specific cancer cell mutations with fewer side effects
questions.correctAnswer: It targets specific cancer cell mutations with fewer side effects
questions.explanation: Targeted therapies like imatinib (Gleevec) for CML are designed to attack specific proteins in cancer cells, causing less damage to healthy cells than traditional chemo.

questions.questionText: Imatinib (Gleevec) is a famous targeted therapy drug for treating _____.
questions.explanation: Imatinib transformed CML (Chronic Myeloid Leukemia) from a fatal disease into a manageable condition. It blocks the BCR-ABL protein that drives CML growth.

questions.questionText: Immunotherapy helps the patient's own immune system fight leukemia cells.
questions.explanation: Immunotherapy treatments like CAR-T cell therapy engineer the patient's own T-cells to recognize and destroy leukemia cells — a major breakthrough in treatment.
